comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There were political moves at the time to re-introduce tobacco, "one of the main crops grown and manufactured in Ireland" in the early 1800s. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/106369218 (Catholic Press (NSW) 9/2/1933). Never knew that!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
There was some hoo hah around tobacco crops in September 1933. It was obviously unseasonally cold, and headlines speak of Tobacco Unharmed By Nights of Frost in The Irish Press on Friday, 15 September 1933:
Mr. J.J. Kelly, Dublin, an authority on tobacco growing, stated yesterday that the frost had not caused damage to tobacco plants which had been grown from acclimatised seeds. Almost all his own crop had been harvested, and he strongly advised all growers to hasten the work while the weather was favourable. Delay would be disastrous, he said.
With regard to Waterford specifically, an article from an Irish Press correspondent wrote from Waterford (on Thursday, 14 September 1933):
The urgent necessity for steps to provide curing and rehandling facilities for tobacco growers in Waterford was emphasised by Mr. F. Power, proprietor of Messrs. W. Power & Co., the well-known seed merchants. Mr. Power was the first to plant tobacco in the Waterford area, and his nursery at Newtown was visited to-day by Mr. J. W. Keller, Departmental Expert, who gave advice to a large number of growers regarding the curing process. ... Mr. Power, who if fortunate in having some accommodation in Newtown, has promised to assist local growers as far as possible in the matter of re-handling.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I'm not convinced. There's no O'Briens in that part of Rathmoylan in 1911 whereas there is over in Brownstown. They could have moved but farms tend to change hands slowly.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Looking more closely at your streetview, I agree that the architectural style of that ruin matches very closely with the Brownstone farm. I don't think it's the same building, but I think it is the right farm.

And that census record with a William O'Brien is good, too.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: I remember my headmaster telling us that there was an Irish cigarette called Ballyowen and if one was ever offered the retort was " you can smoke your bally own" Apparently they were foul fags. Tobacco Bill August 1934 Quote from Dr.Ryan Minister for Agriculture. "We are equally anxious from that point of view that the consumption of tobacco should remain at its present level. In order to maintain the consumption of tobacco, it is important that we should not rush suddenly into the growing of Irish tobacco. Some people, if presented immediately with an Irish-grown cigarette or an Irish tobacco mixture for a pipe might, on account of the very sudden change, stop smoking altogether. We have to try to avoid that." The building in the photograph has 10-12ft eaves and is a more substantial building compared to those at the Brownstown farm. Arch is stone not brick. I'm still convinced its the building (Rathmoylan House) with lean-to...... in the centre of this Bing view. binged.it/1ggL2iQ

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] ROFL!!! That is such a great wee snippet of history you have found!!

comment.author: 48236157@N02
comment._content: I wouldn't have thought tobacco! Thank you.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Holy moly. That quote is mind blowing ("let's not rush into making our own product until we can make a good job of it - if we make a bad job of it we'll might kill the market for the product entirely"). A great find. The logic is hideously perverse. Made all the more bizarre (and telling of how time changes attitudes) by the fact that it's a medical doctor (a cancer specialist no less) and politician talking about tobacco!!! I hadn't read anything about Ireland's tobacco experiments in the past, but Ryan's 1933 Act and this summary are interesting. (scroll down to the bit under the "Dev's protectionism" sub-heading for Ryan/O'Riain's influence). A cancer specialist doctor and politician protecting the cigarette industry: Mind = Blown. In any case, I can't add much to the location discussion. There are a few placenames in Waterford associated with tobacco. "Poll an Tobac" by Ballyvoyle outside Dungarvan implies smuggling rather than growing. Whereas the "Tobacco Fields" by Gortaclade near Kilmeadan is more definitive. But the Rathmoylan / Brownstown / O'Brien connection looks the strongest so far.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content:
A very interesting photo, I wasn't aware that tobacco was grown in Waterford. I shared this photo on Facebook on the Waterford History Group page and one of the members, William Power, has identified the man seated second right in the front row as his Grand Uncle Peter Power. William believes he may be able to identify some more people in the photo.
OwenMacC has the correct location by the way, its Rathmoylan House (most Waterford people pronounce it as Raa whalen)

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content:
This is a piece written by Joe falvey of the Munster Express, a local Waterford Newspaper

Believe it or not part of the Dunmore Road could well have been renamed or popularly dubbed Tobacco Road back in the 30’s and 40’s of the last century. I came across this in a publication entitled ‘Reminiscences of Waterford’ where I read that the first plantation of Tobacco ever grown commercially in this country was sown by Messrs. Power and Co. at Glenville in the early thirties. Schoolboys of today at De la Salle College may interested to learn that experimental plots of Tobacco were successfully grown there in 1932! 
Power’s Nurseries was developed there on the lands which were formerly part of the Goff estate of Glenville, the latter being described in fascinating detail by Annabel Davis-Goff in her autobiographical ‘ Walled Garden’. Snowcream was developed in the early 1950’s on another part of the estate near Glenville House itself.
 Tobacco growing and curing became a significant industry here employing as many as 40 women in the processing plant itself. In September 1933, the Irish Government provided the expertise of a Mr Keller, on loan from the US Department of Agriculture, to advise William and Frank Power of the Nurseries and up to 40 farmers and growers on how to best plant, harvest and cure the crop of tobacco. It was realized at an early stage that to be successfully commercially viable a Curing Rehandling station was required. Frank Power offered to provide 50% of the cost of the facility and was supported further by the other growers which later extended into Wexford and Kilkenny.

The Big Smoke

Waterford could indeed have been described as the ‘Big Smoke’ in that cigar tobacco was grown from the ‘Halliday’ and Zimmer Spanish’ varieties. The Waterford Station as it was known, grew in importance and production of the crop further extended into counties Cork, Carlow and Meath. This commercial crop appealed to farmers as it had only a 4-month grow cycle. The seed was sown in a ‘hot bed’ in mid-March and picked off in April into a mild hot bed or pots and then could be planted out by the 3rd week of May. Harvesting could then commence by the first week of August starting with the lower leaves and then working upwards until harvesting was complete. 
The scale of the local tobacco industry can be gauged by the fact that between 1934 and 1945, the Station at Glenville yielded over one million pounds in revenue- a huge sum back then. This followed the imposition of a levy on home grown tobacco in the year of 1934. At its peak, the Station on the Dunmore Road was processing up to 100 bales a week.
The late Paddy McGuire of McGuires Garden Centre, Woodstown, worked at Power’s Nurseries for over 30 years and joined the company towards the end of the tobacco growing era. Chatting to him some years ago about this enterprise, he recalled the teams of women working there on the tobacco production, curing and curling as they sang away as they worked. It’s the sort of scene we associate today with the cigar factories of Cuba. It came as a surprise to me to have learned that tobacco was so widely grown here in the South-East and that the very hub of this industry was on the Dunmore Road itself. Growing declined after World War II and companies such as Player-Wills reverted to imported tobacco products and local production finally ceased in 1949.

Powering Away

Power Seeds and their nurseries continued to thrive here for many years but scaled back their operation at Glenville in the 70’s and gradually transferred their growing seed business to Ballymountain across the river and today trades very successfully as SeedTech with Roy Power in time taking over from his father Declan. Roy has greatly expanded their sophisticated seedtech business over the past ten years. He represents the fifth generation of Powers who have literally grown the business into its third century since it was established by his great-grand father William Power in 1858 when he opened a nursery shop in King’s Street (now O’Connell Street).
